newsitem.title: IRELAND: No breakthrough in Irish prison siege.
newsitem.headline: No breakthrough in Irish prison siege.

text.p: Negotiations in Dublin's Mountjoy jail on Sunday failed to secure the release of four prison officers held hostage by six inmates armed with makeshift weapons.
The officers, seized on Saturday night, were being held in the prison's segregation unit and were reported to be unharmed.
The prison governor and a senior official from the Irish Justice Department were continuing talks to win their release.
Justice Minister Nora Owen said the six prisoners were protesting against alleged ill-treatment and overcrowding.
The inmates and the officers were well and food was being taken to them during the negotiations, she added.
A representative of the Irish Penal Reform Trust appealed to the prisoners to end their siege.

"I would plead with them to think and consider how they could end it. I think it is quite important that the officers have been humanely treated so in a real sense no real harm has been done," said Valerie Bresnihan.

The six inmates, who were described as armed with iron bars and blood-filled syringes, originally took five prison officers hostage on Saturday night but they released one man shortly after the siege began.

The officer was sent to the prison governor to ask Justice Department officials to intervene in the crisis at the Victorian prison outside Dublin which has a history of problems including drug taking. Some of the prisoners in the jail are HIV positive.

Paul Ward, one of the inmates involved in the siege, and who is facing conspiracy-to-murder charges in connection with the fatal shooting of Irish investigative journalist Veronica Guerin, was also protesting his innocence.
Guerin was gunned down in her car in Dublin last June.
No political prisoners or members of the Irish Republican Army which has fought a 25-year war to oust Britain from Northern Ireland are held at the prison.
